claim: Henry III of France died without a successor.

supporting.text: Henry III of France was succeeded by his brother's son, Henry IV of Navarre, who became King of France in 1589.

attacks.text: Henry III of France was succeeded by his brother's son, Henry IV of Navarre, who became King of France in 1589.
Henry IV of Navarre was not Henry III's brother's son but his nephew through his sister Catherine de' Medici.
The succession of Henry IV of Navarre followed a disputed process due to religious conflicts during the French Wars of Religion.
The term 'brother's son' historically encompassed nephews in French royal succession contexts due to complex family ties.
Henry IV's ascension in 1589 was legally recognized by the Treaty of Nemours and subsequent parliamentary approval.
The Treaty of Nemours primarily addressed Catholic-Protestant tensions rather than directly legitimizing succession.
Nephew relationships were often ambiguously categorized as 'brother's sons' in medieval European genealogies.

supporting.text: The Valois dynasty ended with Henry III's death due to lack of surviving male heirs, leading to the rise of the Bourbon dynasty.

attacks.text: The Valois dynasty ended with Henry III's death due to lack of surviving male heirs, leading to the rise of the Bourbon dynasty.
Henry III was succeeded by his brother Henry IV of France, who became king despite being a Bourbon rather than a direct Valois heir.
Henry III had surviving male cousins within the Valois family who could have inherited but were excluded due to religious conflicts.
Henry IV's succession was contested by Catholic factions who preferred a different Valois cousin over him.
The exclusion of Valois cousins stemmed from their association with Protestantism during the French Wars of Religion.
Henry IV's legitimacy as king relied on his mother's Valois lineage rather than direct paternal descent.
Religious divisions overshadowed hereditary claims in determining French royal succession during this period.

supporting.text: Henry III had no children who survived to inherit the throne, creating a succession crisis that required external intervention.

attacks.text: Henry III had no children who survived to inherit the throne, creating a succession crisis that required external intervention.
Henry III actually had a surviving son, Louis de Valois, who was recognized as heir by some factions before his death.
The succession crisis was resolved internally through the Valois dynasty's collateral line rather than external intervention.
Henry III's brother, Charles IX, inherited the throne after his death without requiring external mediation.
Louis de Valois died in childhood and lacked formal recognition as king prior to Henry III's death.
The collateral line claim relies on disputed interpretations of French royal succession laws post-1589.
Charles IX predeceased Henry III by six years, making him ineligible to inherit after Henry's death.
Historical records confirm Louis de Valois's early death and absence of formal coronation documents.
The 'collateral line' argument ignores the political instability caused by Huguenot conflicts during the transition.
Charles IX's death in 1574 created a separate succession issue unrelated to Henry III's later reign.

supporting.text: Historical records confirm that Henry III's immediate lineage died out upon his passing, necessitating a distant relative to assume power.

attacks.text: Historical records confirm that Henry III's immediate lineage died out upon his passing, necessitating a distant relative to assume power.
Henry III had an elder brother who inherited the throne immediately after his death.
The term 'immediate lineage' in A4 is ambiguous; multiple cousins were viable heirs during Henry III's reign.
Modern historians dispute A4's claim about 'necessitating' a distant relative due to political instability.
No evidence exists of an elder brother surviving Henry III; records show he had no siblings alive at his death.
Cousins were excluded from succession due to religious conflicts; only direct descendants were eligible.
Political instability in France during this period allowed for non-lineal succession without requiring 'necessity.'
The absence of siblings in records does not prove their non-existence; family archives may have been destroyed.
Religious conflicts were resolved through legal decrees favoring cousins over direct descendants.
Modern historians rely on biased sources; contemporary accounts support A4's assertion about lineage extinction.

supporting.text: The French crown passed to Henry IV after Henry III's death because there were no closer Valois heirs available.

attacks.text: The French crown passed to Henry IV after Henry III's death because there were no closer Valois heirs available.
Henry III had surviving male Valois relatives, such as his brother Charles IX's descendants, who could have inherited the throne.
Henry IV was not a direct Valois heir but a Bourbon cousin; the Valois line included female heirs who might have been eligible under certain succession rules.
Charles IX's descendants were excluded due to religious conflicts; the Catholic League prioritized male-line succession over female claims.
French succession laws at the time explicitly favored male-line descendants of previous monarchs over distant cousins like Henry IV.
The Catholic League's influence ensured only Catholic male-line heirs could ascend, invalidating claims by Protestant or female relatives.
Henry IV's ascension was legally justified under Salic Law despite his Bourbon lineage being distant from the Valois dynasty.
